utterance: You did that very well.
speaker: the editor

utterance: I didn't know that little boys in town could drive horses.
speaker: the editor

utterance: Oh, sometimes they can.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: If he had been scared, I think I should have been scared myself; but he was only playing. He has been tied at the rack all day, and he must be hungry.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: Yes, he is hungry, and he wants to see his mate, Rob Roy.
speaker: the editor

utterance: That, said he, is where the high sheriff of the county lives. Do you know Colonel John B. Stith?
speaker: the editor

utterance: Yes,
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: but I thought he lived in a large, fine house. I don't see how he can get in at that door yonder.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: What makes you think he is too big for the door?
speaker: the editor

utterance: Why, the way he goes on,He is always in town talking politics, and he talks bigger than anybody.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: Well,
speaker: the editor

utterance: that is his house. When you get a little older you'll find people who are more disappointing than the high sheriff. Boys are sometimes too big for their breeches, I've heard said, but this is the first time I ever heard that a man could be too big for his house. That is a good one on the colonel.
speaker: the editor

utterance: Just let the horse have his way,
speaker: the editor

utterance: He knows the road better than I do
speaker: the editor

utterance: It is a level road, now,
speaker: the editor

utterance: and Ben Bolt is on the home-stretch.
speaker: the editor

utterance: Is that you, Harbert?
speaker: the editor

utterance: Yes, marster.
speaker: Harbert

utterance: Well, I want you to take Mr. Maxwell here to Mr. Snelson's.
speaker: the editor

utterance: Yasser,
speaker: Harbert

utterance: Snelson is the foreman of the printing-office,
speaker: the editor

utterance: and for the present you are to board with him. I hope he will make things pleasant for you. Goodnight.
speaker: the editor

utterance: I'll hail 'em,
speaker: Harbert

utterance: Ah, and it's the young man! Jump right down and come in to the warmth of the fire. There's something hot on the hearth, where it's waiting you.
speaker: Mr. Snelson

utterance: Run, John,
speaker: Mrs. Snelson

utterance: I just know somebody is stealing my dominicker hen and her chickens. Run!
speaker: Mrs. Snelson

utterance: Let the lad go,
speaker: Mr. Snelson

utterance: He's young and nimble, and whoever's there he'll catch 'em.-Run, lad! and if ye need help, lift your voice and I'll be wit' ye directly.
speaker: Mr. Snelson

utterance: Who are you?
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: Is dis de little marster what come fum town ter work in de paper office?
speaker: Mink

utterance: Yes; who are you, and what are you doing here?
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: I'm name Mink, suh, an' I b'longs to Marse Tom Gaither. I bin run'd away an' I got dat hongry dat it look like I bleedz ter ketch me a 29 chicken. I bin mighty nigh famished, suh. I wish you'd please, suh, excusen me dis time.
speaker: Mink

utterance: Why didn't you break and run when you heard me coming?
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: You wuz dat light-footed, suh, dat I ain't hear you, an' sides dat, I got my han' kotch in dish yer crack, an' you wuz right on top er me 'fo' I kin work it out.
speaker: Mink

utterance: Why don't you stay at home?
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: Dey don't treat me right, suh,
speaker: Mink

utterance: Can you get your hand out of the crack?
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: Lord, yes, suh; I'd 'a done got it out fo' now, but when you lipt on me so quick all my senses wuz skeered out'n me.
speaker: Mink

utterance: Well,
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: get your hand out and stay here till I come back, and I'll fetch you something to eat.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: You ain't foolin' me, is you, little marster?
speaker: Mink

utterance: Do I look like I'd fool you?
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: I can't see you plain, suh,
speaker: Mink

utterance: but you don't talk like it.
speaker: Mink

utterance: Well, get your hand loose and wait.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: It's all right, sir,
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: None of the chickens are gone.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: A great deal of fuss and no feathers,
speaker: Mr. Snelson

utterance: I doubt but it was a mink.
speaker: Mr. Snelson

utterance: Yes,
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: It must have been a Mink, and I'm going to set a bait for him.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: In all this dark?
speaker: Mr. Snelson

utterance: Why, yes,
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: I'll take some biscuit and a piece of corn bread, and scatter them around the hen-house, and if the mink comes back he'll get the bread and leave the chickens alone.
speaker: Joe Maxwell

utterance: Capital!
speaker: Mr. Snelson

utterance: I says to mother here, says I, 'As sure as you're born to die, old woman, that b'y has got the stuff in 'im that they make men out of.' I said them very words. Now di
speaker: Mr. Snelson
